elements.content: A series of MII−LnIII azido-containing complexes: [LnNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (Ln = NdIII (2), EuIII (3), SmIII (4), LaIII (5)) and [GdCu2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (6) have been prepared hydrothermally by using isonicotinate (IN) and azide as bridging ligands with the strategy of synergistic coordination. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and their magnetic properties have been probed by changing the LnIII metal ions and the 3d ions. All of them crystallize in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/n. The structural analyses revealed that alternating EE/EO azido−M chain and RCOO−/Ln chain are presented in these compounds due to coordination synergy. The variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies demonstrate that the magnetic properties of the complexes are dominated by the 3d metal ions.

Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and their magnetic properties have been probed by changing the LnIII metal ions and the 3d ions. All of them crystallize in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/n. The structural analyses revealed that alternating EE/EO azido-M chain and RCOO-/Ln chain are presented in these compounds due to coordination synergy. The variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies demonstrate that the magnetic properties of the complexes are dominated by the 3d metal ions.

elements.content: A series of MII−LnIII azido-containing magnetic complexes have been prepared hydrothermally by using isonicotinate and azide as bridging ligands with the strategy of synergistic coordination. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and their magnetic properties have been studied. It has been shown that their magnetic behaviors depend greatly on the 3d-metal ions.
elements.clean_text: A series of MII-LnIII azido-containing magnetic complexes have been prepared hydrothermally by using isonicotinate and azide as bridging ligands with the strategy of synergistic coordination. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and their magnetic properties have been studied. It has been shown that their magnetic behaviors depend greatly on the 3d-metal ions.

elements.content: The design and construction of 3d-4f coordination polymers have stimulated researchers’ considerable interests, not only for their fascinating architectures, but also for their possible applications as multifunctional materials. Frequently, a well-known principle is employed to synthesize such materials: the 4f ions act as hard acids, thus they prefer oxygen to nitrogen donors and possess high coordination numbers and variable coordination geometries, while 3d metal ions (borderline acids) have strong capability to coordinate to N-donors and O-donors. Therefore, the interesting so-called “synergistic coordination” may happen after introduction of ligands containing N-donor and O-donor into a 3d−4f system. Three good examples of this phenomenon are the compounds [Ln14(μ6-O)(μ3-OH)20(IN)22Cu6X4(H2O)8]·6H2O, [Er7(μ3-O)(μ3-OH)6(bdc)3](IN)9[Cu3X4], and [Ln6(μ3-O)2](IN)18[Cu8(μ4-I)2(μ2-I)3]·H3O.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of 3d-4f coordination polymers have stimulated researchers' considerable interests, not only for their fascinating architectures, but also for their possible applications as multifunctional materials. Frequently, a well-known principle is employed to synthesize such materials: the 4f ions act as hard acids, thus they prefer oxygen to nitrogen donors and possess high coordination numbers and variable coordination geometries, while 3d metal ions (borderline acids) have strong capability to coordinate to N-donors and O-donors. Therefore, the interesting so-called "synergistic coordination" may happen after introduction of ligands containing N-donor and O-donor into a 3d-4f system. Three good examples of this phenomenon are the compounds [Ln14(μ6-O)(μ3-OH)20(IN)22Cu6X4(H2O)8]⋅6H2O, [Er7(μ3-O)(μ3-OH)6(bdc)3](IN)9[Cu3X4], and [Ln6(μ3-O)2](IN)18[Cu8(μ4-I)2(μ2-I)3]⋅H3O.

elements.content: The azido ligand is well-known as an effective ligand to provide strong superexchange pathway between metal ions. Due to this and its various possible binding modes, the azido anion is exhaustively used in constructing magnetic materials whose structures range from 0D (discrete), 1D (chain), 2D (sheet) to 3D (network). The magnetic exchange provided by the azido ligand in its common bridging modes of EE (μ2-1,3) and EO (μ2-1,1) are well studied and usually afford antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic couplings, respectively. Among these structures, various 1D azido-bridged chains, such as uniform single or double EO and EE chain, alternating EE/EO, EE/EE/EO, EE/EE/EE/EO, EE-/EE/EE/EE/EO, etc., have been reported. Careful investigation on the references indicate that such 1D system are mostly based on neutral ligands with monodentate or bidentate (bridging or chelating) donors, especially ligands containing pyridyl groups.
elements.clean_text: The azido ligand is well-known as an effective ligand to provide strong superexchange pathway between metal ions. Due to this and its various possible binding modes, the azido anion is exhaustively used in constructing magnetic materials whose structures range from 0D (discrete), 1D (chain), 2D (sheet) to 3D (network). The magnetic exchange provided by the azido ligand in its common bridging modes of EE (μ2-1,3) and EO (μ2-1,1) are well studied and usually afford antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic couplings, respectively. Among these structures, various 1D azido-bridged chains, such as uniform single or double EO and EE chain, alternating EE/EO, EE/EE/EO, EE/EE/EE/EO, EE-/EE/EE/EE/EO, etc., have been reported. Careful investigation on the references indicate that such 1D system are mostly based on neutral ligands with monodentate or bidentate (bridging or chelating) donors, especially ligands containing pyridyl groups.

elements.content: Previously, a compound [GdNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (1) (IN = isonicotinate) with alternating EE and EO azido chains has been reported. However, further investigation on this synthesis revealed that coordination synergy between 3d−4f metal ions and ligands of IN and azido anions would occur in this system, which is overlooked in our previous work. This strategy has now been used to extend our studies of 3d-4f materials. Herein we report a family of complexes related to [GdNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (1) in which both the LnIII and the 3d metal ions have been varied systematically: [LnNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (Ln = NdIII (2), EuIII (3), SmIII (4), LaIII (5)) and [GdCu2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]·2H2O (6), which show the same overall topology with alternating EE and EO azido chains. Notably, to our knowledge, complexes 1−6 are the first heterometallic 3d−4f in azido-derivatives synthesized by synergistic coordination; moreover, complex 6 is the first heterometallic Cu−4f azido-derivative.

However, further investigation on this synthesis revealed that coordination synergy between 3d-4f metal ions and ligands of IN and azido anions would occur in this system, which is overlooked in our previous work. Herein we report a family of complexes related to [GdNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (1) in which both the LnIII and the 3d metal ions have been varied systematically: [LnNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (Ln = NdIII (2), EuIII (3), SmIII (4), LaIII (5)) and [GdCu2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (6), which show the same overall topology with alternating EE and EO azido chains. Notably, to our knowledge, complexes 1-6 are the first heterometallic 3d-4f in azido-derivatives synthesized by synergistic coordination; moreover, complex 6 is the first heterometallic Cu-4f azido-derivative.

elements.content: The lanthanide nitrate Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (Ln = NdIII, SmIII, LaIII, GdIII) were prepared by dissolving Ln2O3 (99.9%) in nitric acid, followed by drying and crystallization. The EuCl3·6H2O salt were prepared in the same way as Ln(NO3)3·6H2O, using hydrochloric acid to replace nitric acid. Other chemicals were commercially available and used as received. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm−1. Elemental analyses of C, H, N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Magnetic measurements were carried out in the “Servei de Magnetoquímica (Universitat de Barcelona)” on polycrystalline samples with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer working in 2−300 K range. The magnetic field was 0.1 T. The diamagnetic corrections were evaluated from Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The lanthanide nitrate Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Ln = NdIII, SmIII, LaIII, GdIII) were prepared by dissolving Ln2O3 (99.9%) in nitric acid, followed by drying and crystallization. The EuCl3⋅6H2O salt were prepared in the same way as Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O, using hydrochloric acid to replace nitric acid. Other chemicals were commercially available and used as received. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Elemental analyses of C, H, N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Magnetic measurements were carried out in the "Servei de Magnetoquímica (Universitat de Barcelona)" on polycrystalline samples with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer working in 2-300 K range. The magnetic field was 0.1 T. The diamagnetic corrections were evaluated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content:
Complexes 2−5 were prepared by a similar method used for complex 1 as follows.

[NdNi<sub>2</sub>(IN)<sub>5</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.5 mmol), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), isonicotinic acid (2.5 mmol) and H2O (13.5 mL) at the ratio of 1:2:2:5:1500 was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at a rate of 3 °C/h to 160 °C under autogenous pressure. After maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled 6 h to room temperature. The green crystals in ca. 20% yield based on nickel were obtained and washed by water (the crystals were carefully picked one by one). Anal. Calcd for C30H30NdNi2N11O15 (2): C, 34.44; H, 2.89; N, 14.73. Found: C, 34.73; H, 3.23; N, 14.42%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): ν = 2095, 2056, 1651, 1583, 1542, 1412, 857, 779, 687.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Compounds

Complexes 2-5 were prepared by a similar method used for complex 1  as follows.

[NdNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (2)

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), isonicotinic acid (2.5 mmol) and H2O (13.5 mL) at the ratio of 1:2:2:5:1500 was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at a rate of 3 °C/h to 160 °C under autogenous pressure. After maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled 6 h to room temperature. The green crystals in ca. 20% yield based on nickel were obtained and washed by water (the crystals were carefully picked one by one). Anal. Calcd for C30H30NdNi2N11O15 (2): C, 34.44; H, 2.89; N, 14.73. Found: C, 34.73; H, 3.23; N, 14.42%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): ν = 2095, 2056, 1651, 1583, 1542, 1412, 857, 779, 687.

elements.content: Although we have not experienced any problems in this work, azide and its complexes are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of the materials should be prepared and handled with care. All the experiments were carried out in an isolated room. All the experimenters should be equipped with safety protection.
elements.clean_text:
Caution!

Although we have not experienced any problems in this work, azide and its complexes are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of the materials should be prepared and handled with care. All the experiments were carried out in an isolated room. All the experimenters should be equipped with safety protection.

elements.content: The chosen crystals were mounted on a glass fiber. All diffraction data were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). The positions of metal atoms were located from E-map by direct-method, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier syntheses and least-squares refinement cycles, and finally refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were placed theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically as riding atoms. Details of the crystal data collection and refinement parameters for 2−6 are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

The chosen crystals were mounted on a glass fiber. All diffraction data were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). The positions of metal atoms were located from E-map by direct-method, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier syntheses and least-squares refinement cycles, and finally refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were placed theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically as riding atoms. Details of the crystal data collection and refinement parameters for 2-6 are given in Table .

For 2−5, large block green crystals with jade-green powder were obtained at 160 °C in hydrothermal conditions. The crystals can be separated from the powder by washing with methanol or water and picked one by one. For 6, the reaction temperature determined its crystallization, if the temperature was over 140 °C, black powder deposited due to the instability and decomposition of azido−copper complexes. At lower temperatures (<100 °C), only a green powder was obtained. Big block black crystals with dark green powder were obtained for 6 at 120 °C, the crystals could be easily separated from the powder by washing with water. Our attempts to obtain the 3d-4f compounds reported here using usual benchtop chemistry were unsuccessful. The hydrothermal method was proved to be effective to synthesize mesostable substances, and complexes 1−6 may be such mesostable compounds that could only be synthesized hydrothermally. The IR (cm−1) spectra of the complexes showed absorption peaks in the range of 2098−2053 cm−1 are the results of the presence of bridging azido anions. Double peaks in all the five cases are indicative of double bridging modes of the azido.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

For 2-5, large block green crystals with jade-green powder were obtained at 160 °C in hydrothermal conditions. The crystals can be separated from the powder by washing with methanol or water and picked one by one. For 6, the reaction temperature determined its crystallization, if the temperature was over 140 °C, black powder deposited due to the instability and decomposition of azido-copper complexes. At lower temperatures (<100 °C), only a green powder was obtained. Big block black crystals with dark green powder were obtained for 6 at 120 °C, the crystals could be easily separated from the powder by washing with water. Our attempts to obtain the 3d-4f compounds reported here using usual benchtop chemistry were unsuccessful. The hydrothermal method was proved to be effective to synthesize mesostable substances, and complexes 1-6 may be such mesostable compounds that could only be synthesized hydrothermally. The IR (cm-1) spectra of the complexes showed absorption peaks in the range of 2098-2053 cm-1 are the results of the presence of bridging azido anions. Double peaks in all the five cases are indicative of double bridging modes of the azido.

elements.content: In fact, complexes 2−5 are isostructural to compound 1, which show a complicated 3D structure, and their structural parameters (bond distances and angles, and dihedral angles) are also similar to 1. Herein, only 2 will be described in detail as example. The crystallographic asymmetric unit of 2 consists of a NdIII ion, two nonequivalent NiII (Ni1 and Ni2) ions, two nonequivalent azido ligands, and five different IN anions, two of which are tridentate (μ3-N,O,O), and three of which are bidentate (μ2-N,O). The structure also contains coordinated water to the NdIII ions (one each), and to the Ni1 ions (two each, in a trans arrangement), and also two uncoordinated water molecules trapped within the lattice. The coordination spheres and linkage of the ligands are shown in Figure (top).

Crystal Structures

[LnNi2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (Ln = Nd(2), Eu(3), Sm(4), La(5))

In fact, complexes 2-5 are isostructural to compound 1, which show a complicated 3D structure, and their structural parameters (bond distances and angles, and dihedral angles) are also similar to 1. Herein, only 2 will be described in detail as example. The crystallographic asymmetric unit of 2 consists of a NdIII ion, two nonequivalent NiII (Ni1 and Ni2) ions, two nonequivalent azido ligands, and five different IN anions, two of which are tridentate (μ3-N,O,O), and three of which are bidentate (μ2-N,O). The structure also contains coordinated water to the NdIII ions (one each), and to the Ni1 ions (two each, in a trans arrangement), and also two uncoordinated water molecules trapped within the lattice. The coordination spheres and linkage of the ligands are shown in Figure  (top).

elements.content: The NdIII ions are seven-coordinated, although there are also two weak interactions between Nd···O (belonging to carboxylates with the other oxygen already bound to the metal) which are shown as striped bonds in Figure (top). Each NdIII ion is bound to four μ3-N,O,O IN, two μ2-N,O IN, and a water molecule. The tridentate IN anions bridge the NdIII ions into 1D zigzag chains by the carboxylate groups (Figure , bottom). These μ3-N,O,O IN anions also coordinate to Ni2 ions via the nitrogen atoms. The Ni2 ions are in turn connected into chains by two alternating EE and EO modes of double azido bridges [Ni2−N6 = 2.099(4), Ni2−N8A = 2.079(4), Ni2−N9 = 2.110(4), Ni2−N9A = 2.147(4) Å]. Thus, 2D sheets are generated due to the synergistic coordination of the inorganic azido and organic IN ligands to the 3d and 4f metals, respectively (Figure , top), which is different from the synergistic coordination between inorganic I ligand and organic IN ligand in the compounds of ref. Considering the extending direction of pyridyl ring and the distances of N4···N3 (3.571 Å) and N4···N3A (4.674 Å) which is close to the distances of M···M for double EO (≈3.3 Å) and EE (≈5 Å) azido bridges, the construction of alternating EE/EO azido chains is preferred.

These μ3-N,O,O IN anions also coordinate to Ni2 ions via the nitrogen atoms. The Ni2 ions are in turn connected into chains by two alternating EE and EO modes of double azido bridges [Ni2-N6 = 2.099(4), Ni2-N8A = 2.079(4), Ni2-N9 = 2.110(4), Ni2-N9A = 2.147(4) Å]. Thus, 2D sheets are generated due to the synergistic coordination of the inorganic azido and organic IN ligands to the 3d and 4f metals, respectively (Figure , top), which is different from the synergistic coordination between inorganic I ligand and organic IN ligand in the compounds of ref. Considering the extending direction of pyridyl ring and the distances of N4⋅⋅⋅N3 (3.571 Å) and N4⋅⋅⋅N3A (4.674 Å) which is close to the distances of M⋅⋅⋅M for double EO (~3.3 Å) and EE (~5 Å) azido bridges, the construction of alternating EE/EO azido chains is preferred.

elements.content: Additionally, the three different bidentate IN anions, two of which project above and below the aforementioned sheets from the NdIII ions, coordinate to the Ni1 ions (Figure , top) in an equatorial arrangement. One type of bidentate IN bridges the Ni1 ions into linear chains, coordinating via its pyridyl nitrogen to one Ni1, and via a carboxylate oxygen to another. Thus, each Ni1 coordinates to one of these ligands via the nitrogen, and to another, trans from the first, via an oxygen atom. The two other trans positions are occupied by the remaining two types of bidentate IN anions. These anions are N-bound and connect the Ni1 cations to the NdIII ions: one to a Nd/Ni2 sheet below, and one to a Nd/Ni2 sheet above. Thus the Nd/Ni2 sheets are connected via the Ni1 ions into a single 3D network. The complicated overall topology is shown in Figure (bottom).

The two other trans positions are occupied by the remaining two types of bidentate IN anions. elements.content: The overall topology of 6 is very similar to 1−5, but there are some pronounced differences in the 3d-metal coordination sphere (Figure , middle). In 6, both the EE and EO azido ligands take the asymmetric bridging mode, due to the Jahn−Teller effect of CuII ions. This was not found in the NiII-LnIII series of compounds 1−5. The Cu−N(azido) distances are Cu2−N8 = 1.957(5), Cu2−N9 = 1.971(5), Cu2−N6 = 2.644, Cu2−N9A = 2.648 Å, compared to Ni−N(azido) in the range from 2.05 to 2.15 Å in 2. Strictly speaking, the alternating EE and EO chain can be regarded as isolated monomeric copper units linked by weak coordination interactions, which result in the different magnetic properties of 6 and 2−5. Notably, complex 6 is the first example of heterometallic Cu-4f system with azido ligands.

[GdCu2(IN)5(N3)2(H2O)3]⋅2H2O (6)

The overall topology of 6 is very similar to 1-5, but there are some pronounced differences in the 3d-metal coordination sphere (Figure , middle). In 6, both the EE and EO azido ligands take the asymmetric bridging mode, due to the Jahn-Teller effect of CuII ions. This was not found in the NiII-LnIII series of compounds 1-5. The Cu-N(azido) distances are Cu2-N8 = 1.957(5), Cu2-N9 = 1.971(5), Cu2-N6 = 2.644, Cu2-N9A = 2.648 Å, compared to Ni-N(azido) in the range from 2.05 to 2.15 Å in 2. Strictly speaking, the alternating EE and EO chain can be regarded as isolated monomeric copper units linked by weak coordination interactions, which result in the different magnetic properties of 6 and 2-5. Notably, complex 6 is the first example of heterometallic Cu-4f system with azido ligands.

elements.content: All the complexes presented here, as mentioned above, are isostructural and the magnetic pathways will be the same. The structure can be viewed, from the magnetic point of view, as three independent sublattices that are linked by the pyridinecarboxylato groups. First, the LnIII ions form chains along the a axis of the unit cell linked by syn−anti carboxylato bridges. For transition metal ions this magnetic pathway is known to be small and antiferromagnetic, and it is expected to be similar for lanthanide ions, except in the case of the NiII−LaIII compound, 5, since LaIII has no unpaired electrons and is thus diamagnetic. Second, the M1 ions (M is NiII for 1−5 and CuII for 6) are linked into a 1D chain along the c axis of the unit cell by the pyridinecarboxylato ligands; the M1-M1 distances being on average 9 Å for 1−6; this bridging mode of the ligand always creates very small antiferromagnetic coupling. Last, but most important from the magnetic properties, the M2 ions (M is NiII for 1−5 and CuII for 6) are bridged either by double end-on or double end-to-end azido ligands, in an alternating chain fashion. This alternating bridging mode of the azido ligands leads to a chain of two alternating J values. A close examination of the angles around the azido ligands and the metal ions (M2−N−M2 angles around 100 ° for the end-on azido ligands, and dihedral angles of 38 ° for 6 and of the order of 65 ° for 1−5 for the double end-to-end azido bridges) allow us to conclude that the end-to-end bridges will lead to weak antiferromagnetic coupling, while the end-on bridges will mediate ferromagnetic coupling between the metal ions. Thus, the overall behavior of the magnetic chain will be that of an antiferromagnetic 1D system, leading to a net magnetic moment of zero for the chain due to the cancelation of the spins. Furthermore, the low temperature magnetic properties of the samples will be dominated by the ratio between the two J values of opposite sign. The two transition metal sublattices are linked via the pyridinecarboxylate ligands by the lanthanide lattice into a 3D network but the M−M distances are very long. The shortest M1−M2 distances are of the order of 8 Å in 1 to 6, and the interchain M1−M1 distances are of the order of 9 Å and the interchain M2−M2 distances are between 16 and 19 Å. So the two transition metal sublattices can be considered magnetically independent, only at very low temperatures the interaction between will be important, and their magnetic behaviours can be interpreted separately.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

All the complexes presented here, as mentioned above, are isostructural and the magnetic pathways will be the same. The structure can be viewed, from the magnetic point of view, as three independent sublattices that are linked by the pyridinecarboxylato groups. First, the LnIII ions form chains along the a axis of the unit cell linked by syn-anti carboxylato bridges. For transition metal ions this magnetic pathway is known to be small and antiferromagnetic, and it is expected to be similar for lanthanide ions, except in the case of the NiII-LaIII compound, 5, since LaIII has no unpaired electrons and is thus diamagnetic. Second, the M1 ions (M is NiII for 1-5 and CuII for 6) are linked into a 1D chain along the c axis of the unit cell by the pyridinecarboxylato ligands; the M1-M1 distances being on average 9 Å for 1-6; this bridging mode of the ligand always creates very small antiferromagnetic coupling. Last, but most important from the magnetic properties, the M2 ions (M is NiII for 1-5 and CuII for 6) are bridged either by double end-on or double end-to-end azido ligands, in an alternating chain fashion. This alternating bridging mode of the azido ligands leads to a chain of two alternating J values. A close examination of the angles around the azido ligands and the metal ions (M2-N-M2 angles around 100 ° for the end-on azido ligands, and dihedral angles of 38 ° for 6 and of the order of 65 ° for 1-5 for the double end-to-end azido bridges) allow us to conclude that the end-to-end bridges will lead to weak antiferromagnetic coupling, while the end-on bridges will mediate ferromagnetic coupling between the metal ions. Thus, the overall behavior of the magnetic chain will be that of an antiferromagnetic 1D system, leading to a net magnetic moment of zero for the chain due to the cancelation of the spins. Furthermore, the low temperature magnetic properties of the samples will be dominated by the ratio between the two J values of opposite sign. The two transition metal sublattices are linked via the pyridinecarboxylate ligands by the lanthanide lattice into a 3D network but the M-M distances are very long. The shortest M1-M2 distances are of the order of 8 Å in 1 to 6, and the interchain M1-M1 distances are of the order of 9 Å and the interchain M2-M2 distances are between 16 and 19 Å. So the two transition metal sublattices can be considered magnetically independent, only at very low temperatures the interaction between will be important, and their magnetic behaviours can be interpreted separately.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of complex 5 allow us to study the magnetic behavior of the Ni lattices, since the LnIII ion in 5 is LaIII which has no unpaired electrons. DC magnetic susceptibility was measured at an applied field of 0.3 T. χm vs T plot has a visible change in the slope at 43 K. At 43 K the χ M curve (Figure , top) rises to a plateau, but no maximum is observed, and then the susceptibility rises again. The χ M T value at 300 K is 2.4 cm3 K mol−1. This value is in good agreement with the expected value for two noninteracting NiII ions, which would be 2.0 cm3 K mol−1 with an ideal spin-only g value of 2.0. The temperature dependence of χ M T product decreases on cooling, as expected due to the ferromagnetic/antiferromagnetic coupling pattern found in the Ni2 alternating chains. At 43 K there is a peak in the χ M T vs T plot, followed by a sharp drop at low temperatures, caused by the zero-field splitting of NiII. In order to establish the possibility of long-range order or not, a zero-field cool/field-cool measurement with a 50 G applied field (Figure , bottom) was performed, which showed a hysteresis in the susceptibility. Additionally, an ac magnetic susceptibility measurement was performed with an alternating ac field of 4 G (, Figure S1). It showed a very small maximum in the susceptibility at 41 K, after which a rise of the susceptibility was observed. No out-of-phase signal was observed. The maximum is caused by the antiferromagnetic ordering of the Ni2−azido chain of alternating ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions, which leads to a total cancelation of the spins, and the rise seen at lower temperatures reflects the chain of isolated Ni1 ions which follow the Curie law. The field dependence of the magnetization at 2 K for complex 5 is shown in Figure , the magnetization saturates at a value of nearly 2.0, as expected for one isolated NiII ion. This confirms that the alternating chain of Ni2 ions has no net spin (AF coupling) at this temperature and the measurement detects only the magnetically isolated Ni1 ions.

elements.content: For complexes 1−4, with LnIII ions having unpaired f-electrons the susceptibility curves have the same shape as that of complex 5, as expected if the magnetic behavior of the sample is dominated by the Ni1 and Ni2 sublattices. As can be seen in Figure , the only difference between the different curves is the magnitude of the susceptibility, which depends on the number of unpaired electrons of each LnIII ion. Table summarizes the experimental χ M T products for complexes 1−5 and the expected χ M T values at room temperature for the isolated LnIII ions. In all cases, there is a very good agreement with the predicted susceptibilities for two NiII ions and a LnIII and the experimental values.

Magnetic properties of complexes <bold>1−5</bold> Ln(III) χ M T (Ln, 300 K, cm3 K mol−1) χM T (complex, 300 K, cm3 K mol−1) Gd 7.80−8.00 10.00 2 Nd 1.50−1.62 4.00 3 Eu 1.36−1.50 3.80 4 Sm 0.28−0.36 2.60 5 La 2.44

Observed susceptibility values for isolated Ln(III) ions.

Complex 1 contains GdIII (f7), with a ground state 8S7/2 and has no spin−orbit coupling. The χΜ T at room temperature is in good agreement with the expected for two NiII ions and a GdIII. Complex 2 contains NdIII (f3), with 4I9/2 ground-state and strong spin−orbit coupling. The χΜ T product at room temperature is slightly larger than expected for the two NiII and one NdIII ions. Complexes 3 and 4 contain EuIII and SmIII. These are the only two LnIII ions in which the ground-state is not perfectly isolated due to its relatively small spin−orbit coupling parameter. Thus, the excited terms are close to the ground-state and are populated at room temperature. EuIII (f) has 7F0 ground-state with a 7F1 excited-state at 400−500 cm−1 approximately. The calculated χΜ T value assuming that only the diamagnetic ground-state is populated will be 0 cm3 mol−1 K. However, the presence of the paramagnetic excited state 7F1 at only 400 cm−1 gives always χΜ T values close to 1.5 cm3 mol−1 K at room temperature, which is why the observed χΜ T value for complex 4 is not only that of the NiII sublattices. SmIII (f) has an excited state 6H7/2, 1000 cm−1 above its 6H5/2 ground-state. If only the ground-state were populated, the calculated χ M T value would be close to 0.1 cm3 mol−1 K but the presence of the first excited state 6H7/2 at ca. 1000 cm−1 leads to χΜ T values close to 0.4 cm3 mol−1 K at room temperature. The magnetization at 2 K for complexes 2−5 are shown in Figure and show saturation values as expected for one NiII and the respective LnIII ion.
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 contains GdIII (f7), with a ground state 8S7/2 and has no spin-orbit coupling. The χΜ T at room temperature is in good agreement with the expected for two NiII ions and a GdIII. Complex 2 contains NdIII (f3), with 4I9/2 ground-state and strong spin-orbit coupling. The χΜ T product at room temperature is slightly larger than expected for the two NiII and one NdIII ions. Complexes 3 and 4 contain EuIII and SmIII. These are the only two LnIII ions in which the ground-state is not perfectly isolated due to its relatively small spin-orbit coupling parameter. Thus, the excited terms are close to the ground-state and are populated at room temperature. EuIII (f) has 7F0 ground-state with a 7F1 excited-state at 400-500 cm-1 approximately. The calculated χΜ T value assuming that only the diamagnetic ground-state is populated will be 0 cm3 mol-1 K. However, the presence of the paramagnetic excited state 7F1 at only 400 cm-1 gives always χΜ T values close to 1.5 cm3 mol-1 K at room temperature, which is why the observed χΜ T value for complex 4 is not only that of the NiII sublattices. SmIII (f) has an excited state 6H7/2, 1000 cm-1 above its 6H5/2 ground-state. If only the ground-state were populated, the calculated χ M  T value would be close to 0.1 cm3 mol-1 K but the presence of the first excited state 6H7/2 at ca. 1000 cm-1 leads to χΜ T values close to 0.4 cm3 mol-1 K at room temperature. The magnetization at 2 K for complexes 2-5 are shown in Figure  and show saturation values as expected for one NiII and the respective LnIII ion.

elements.content: Complex 6 contains CuII and GdIII ions. The structure is very similar to that of complexes 1−5, with expected differences in bond distances since now the transition metal is CuII and not NiII. DC magnetic susceptibility was measured at an applied field of 0.3 T. As can be seen in Figure (top), the χ M T value at 300 K is 9.27 cm3 K mol−1. This value is in good agreement with the expected value for two noninteracting CuII ions and a GdIII, which would be 8.75 cm3 K mol−1 with an ideal spin-only g value of 2.0. The value of χ M T remains nearly constant down to 20 K, and then it slightly drops to 8.33 cm3 K mol−1. As done in the series of NiII complexes, the magnetic behavior of each nonequivalent cation will be analyzed separately. The GdIII ions form a pseudo 1D network and are practically uncoupled. As discussed earlier, there are two types of CuII ions in the structure. Cu1 forms a chain of CuII centers bridged through the isonicotinic acid and result in shortest Cu1−Cu1 distance of average 9 Å, which will lead to uncoupled CuII ions. The Cu2 centers form a 1D alternating EO/EO azido chain, which leads to alternating ferromagnetic/antiferromagnetic interactions that will give a total S = 0 for the chain. However, due to the axial distortion of the CuII ion, the Cu2−N bond distances alternate average values of 1.97 and 2.65 Å, resulting in very weak coupling through the azido ligands. This is reflected in Figure (top), since only at very low temperatures the overall value of χ M T drops to that of one GdIII and one CuII, ca. 8.375 cm3 K mol−1. This is also supported by the magnetization vs field plot of Figure (bottom), which tends to a saturation value of 8.5 at 5 T, slightly below the expected 9 for one GdIII and two CuII ions.

elements.content: We have extended the 3d−4f azido/RCOO− system from NiII−GdIII to NiII−LnIII and CuII−GdIII. Five new compounds have been obtained that show the same overall topology with alternating EE and EO azido chains. As a result, we have successfully proved that synergistic coordination occurred in the generation of these complexes. It is remarkable that complexes 1−6 are the first heterometallic 3d-4f in azido-derivatives synthesized by synergistic coordination, and complex 6 is the first heterometallic Cu-4f in azido-derivative as well. The study of the magnetic properties of the series of complexes has shown that the magnetic behavior is dominated by the 3d metal sublattices (NiII for 1−5 and CuII for 6) due to the very weak coupling between the LnIII and 3d-metal ions through the pyrirdinecarboxylato ligand. Constructing novel azido compounds based on the synergistic coordination, by controlling the extending direction of IN and utilizing other carboxylates containing N-donors, are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have extended the 3d-4f azido/RCOO- system from NiII-GdIII to NiII-LnIII and CuII-GdIII. Five new compounds have been obtained that show the same overall topology with alternating EE and EO azido chains. As a result, we have successfully proved that synergistic coordination occurred in the generation of these complexes. It is remarkable that complexes 1-6 are the first heterometallic 3d-4f in azido-derivatives synthesized by synergistic coordination, and complex 6 is the first heterometallic Cu-4f in azido-derivative as well. The study of the magnetic properties of the series of complexes has shown that the magnetic behavior is dominated by the 3d metal sublattices (NiII for 1-5 and CuII for 6) due to the very weak coupling between the LnIII and 3d-metal ions through the pyrirdinecarboxylato ligand. Constructing novel azido compounds based on the synergistic coordination, by controlling the extending direction of IN and utilizing other carboxylates containing N-donors, are underway.

cln_elements.content:
Complexes 2−5 were prepared by a similar method used for complex 1 as follows.

[NdNi<sub>2</sub>(IN)<sub>5</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.5 mmol), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), isonicotinic acid (2.5 mmol) and H2O (13.5 mL) at the ratio of 1:2:2:5:1500 was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at a rate of 3 °C/h to 160 °C under autogenous pressure. After maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled 6 h to room temperature. The green crystals in ca. 20% yield based on nickel were obtained and washed by water (the crystals were carefully picked one by one). Anal. Calcd for C30H30NdNi2N11O15 (2): C, 34.44; H, 2.89; N, 14.73. Found: C, 34.73; H, 3.23; N, 14.42%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): ν = 2095, 2056, 1651, 1583, 1542, 1412, 857, 779, 687.

[EuNi<sub>2</sub>(IN)<sub>5</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 was prepared in the same way as 2, using EuCl3·6H2O instead of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O, as green crystals in ca. 20% yield based on nickel. Anal. Calcd for C30H30EuNi2N11O15 (3): C, 34.19, H, 2.87, N, 14.62. Found: C, 34.51; H, 3.08; N, 14.72%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): ν = 2097, 2056, 1655, 1586, 1543, 1412, 858, 779, 695.

[SmNi<sub>2</sub>(IN)<sub>5</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Complex 4 was prepared in the same way as 2, using Sm(NO3)3·6H2O instead of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O. Green crystals yielded in ca. 20% based on nickel. Anal. Calcd for C30H30SmNi2N11O15 (4): C, 34.24, H, 2.87, N, 14.64. Found: C, 34.73; H, 2.82; N, 14.70%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 2097, 2056, 1654, 1585, 1543, 1413, 859, 779, 696.

[LaNi<sub>2</sub>(IN)<sub>5</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (5)

Complex 5 was prepared in the same way as 2, using La(NO3)3·6H2O instead of Nd(NO3)3·6H2O. Green crystals yielded in ca. 30% based on nickel. Anal. Calcd for C30H30LaNi2N11O15 (5): C, 34.62; H, 2.91; N, 14.80. Found: C, 33.47; H, 2.71; N, 14.93%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 2094, 2056, 1650, 1582, 1541, 1411, 856, 779, 686.

[GdCu<sub>2</sub>(IN)<sub>5</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (6)

Complex 6 was prepared in the similar procedure as 2, but some modifications were made. A mixture of Gd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.25 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (0.5 mmol), isonicotinic acid (1.25 mmol) and H2O (13.5 mL) at the ratio of 1:2:2:5:3000 was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at a rate of 3 °C/h to 120 °C under autogenous pressure. After maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled 6 h to room temperature. The black crystals in ca. 20% yield based on copper were obtained and washed by water. Anal. Calcd. for C30H30GdCu2N11O15 (6): C, 33.71, H, 2.83, N 14.41. Found: C, 34.01; H, 2.91; N, 14.32%. IR (KBr, cm−1): ν = 2098, 2053, 1652, 1583, 1542, 1412, 857, 779, 692.
